Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Multi-Proxy Paleoecological Records from the Shark River Estuary: Wetland Evolution in the Light of Paleohurricane Activity and Sea-Level Changes

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This doctoral dissertation research project will examine the long-term response of coastal wetland communities to past sea-level fluctuations and recurrent hurricane strikes to reveal the Holocene history of mangrove forests in the Everglades of southwestern Florida. No palynological record older than 5,000 years before the present currently exists for this region. The doctoral student will help fill this gap by integrating various paleoecological methods including palynological, x-ray fluorescence, and loss-on-ignition analyses to produce the first pollen record and paleo-hurricane proxy record over the past 7,500 years and reveal the oldest depositional history of the coastal Everglades. Radioactive isotope analyses of 14-carbon, 137-cesium, and 210-lead will be used to date sediment samples collected from locations along and near the Shark River Slough. Analyses of a sediment core previously collected at the mouth of the Shark River Slough had identified a distinctive stratigraphic signature for Hurricane Wilma, an intense hurricane that directly struck the study area in 2005. This storm deposit will be used as a modern analog for identifying other hurricane events in other cores. Analyses of these cores and the resulting vegetation chronologies that will be produced should help reveal the response of mangrove forests to past sea-level rise and hurricane disturbance.

Coastal mangrove forests in the Everglades are an important natural resource. By coupling palynology with paleotempestology, the results of this study will shed light on the response of the mangrove ecosystem to multiple extreme events over timescales of centuries to millennia. Such a database addresses two key issues in the management and restoration of the Everglades coastal ecosystems: rapid sea-level rise and extreme hurricane disturbances. The palynological results will provide guidelines and background knowledge for management planning for coastal protection and restoration. This project also should help identify the frequency of catastrophic hurricanes in South Florida, which is information vital for risk assessment and disaster management in the region. As a Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement award, this project will provide support to enable a promising student to establish an independent research career.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Summary

            This project examined the paleoecological records from the Shark River Estuary in the southwestern part of the Everglades National Park (ENP), Florida, to reconstruct the history of the coastal mangrove ecosystem in the Florida Coastal Everglades over the last 6,000 years. Approximately 15 meters of sediments were collected from 4 study sites (Figure 1) and subjected to various palynological, sedimentological, and geochemical analyses to produce multi-proxy records of coastal environmental changes (Figure 2, 3).

            The analytical results of our sediment samples revealed that Holocene sea-level rise over the past 5,000 years was the predominant cause of vegetation changes in the Shark River Estuary. The Shark River Estuary underwent three major transformations during the last 6,000 years (Figure 3): (1) Short-hydroperiod marl prairies were progressively replaced by long hydroperiod prairies and sloughs from ∼5,700 to 3,800 cal yr BP. (2) Long hydroperiod prairies and sloughs were replaced by brackish marsh from 3,800 to 2,000 cal yr BP. (3) A significant expansion of mangroves occurred over the last 2,000 years. At ~1,100 years ago, as the shoreline became stabilized, the present mixed mangrove forest was formed at the mouth of the Shark River. In addition to Hurricane Wilma in 2005, the southwestern Everglades were directly impacted at least six times by major hurricanes at ~3,000, 1,700, 950, 580, 350, and 120 years ago (Figure 4).

 

Intellectual Merits

            In order to predict how subtropical coastal wetlands will respond to future global climate changes, a long-term ecological study is necessary for understanding the response of mangrove ecosystems to past sea-level fluctuations. However, no pollen records older than 5,000 years were available in the literature from the Florida Coastal Everglades. Our 5,700-year record from 4 coring sites has filled this gap and revealed the evolution of coastal wetlands along the Shark River Estuary (Figure 2, 3). In addition, no long-term hurricane record had been produced from the Everglades due to its unique hydrological and geological conditions. Our stratigraphic study of the deposits from category 3 Hurricane Wilma revealed that it has a unique palynological, sedimentological, and geochemical signature. By using this hurricane fingerprint as a modern analog, we produced the first paleo-record of hurricane activities for the Everglades (Figure 4). Finally, this study has documented the development of the mangrove ecosystem in response to sea level rise, climate change, and natural disturbances over the last several millennia. Such a dataset is vital for predicting how the Everglades mangrove ecosystem will respond to future global climate changes in this century.

 

Broader Impacts

            Coastal mangrove forests are important natural resources that provide many goods and services to society. This study addresses two key issues in the management and restoration of the Everglades coastal ecosystems: rapid sea-level rise and extreme hurricane disturbances. The pollen results provide guidelines and background knowledge for policymakers in their management planning for coastal protection and restoration. This study produces the first paleo-record of catastrophic hurricane landfalls for South Florida, which is vital for risk assessment and disaster management for stakeholders in the study region.
